sen.j: 沓頬（くつつら）は、鳥山石燕による妖怪画集『百器徒然袋』にある日本の妖怪。
sen.e: Kutsutsura is a Japanese specter portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idlenss).

Kutsu-tsura (literally, shoe cheek) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive])

sen.e: The two figures are portrayed; one is a hairy kutsu (shoe), and another is a human-like figure transformed from a crown.

sen.j: 沓の妖怪の方は瓜の畑で瓜を盗み、冠の妖怪の方は李の木の下で李を盗むとされる。
sen.e: It is said that Kutsu specter steals gourds on the gourds field while the Crown specter steals plums from the plum tree.
It is said that the kutsu yokai (shoe specter) steals gourds from gourd fields while the kanmuri yokai (courtier's cap specter) steals plums from plum trees.

sen.j: これは中国の書物『文選 (書物)』にもある諺「李下の冠、瓜田の履」に由来するものである。
sen.e: It was created based on the proverb, "Be careful not to invite the least suspicion," which is also included in the Chinese book "Monzen" (ancient Chinese poems).

This is based on a proverb, "Rika no Kanmuri, Kaden no Kutsu" (literally, lifting a courtier's cap under the plum tree, and stepping into the gourd field, which is a Chinese counterpart of "Be careful not to invite the least suspicion"), which is also included in the Chinese book "Monzen" (ancient Chinese poems).
